ticket.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field
ticket.original-body:
The DIV tag generated inside form_for and form_tag by default has the style @@@'margin:0;padding:0'@@@ and the input fields inside it (_method and authenticity_token) are hidden, so it usually has no effect on the HTML page, but sometimes you need to have a CSS class on it to avoid some layout/float issues.
This patch adds a configuration option that can be used like this: @@@ config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form.merge!(:class=>'hideMe') config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form.merge!(:class=>'hideMe', :style=>'display:none') @@@
ticket.latest-body:
The DIV tag generated inside form_for and form_tag by default has the style @@@'margin:0;padding:0'@@@ and the input fields inside it (_method and authenticity_token) are hidden, so it usually has no effect on the HTML page, but sometimes you need to have a CSS class on it to avoid some layout/float issues.
This patch adds a configuration option that can be used like this: @@@ config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form.merge!(:class=>'hideMe') config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form.merge!(:class=>'hideMe', :style=>'display:none') @@@
ticket.original-body-html:
The DIV tag generated inside form_for and form_tag by default has the style @@@'margin:0;padding:0'@@@ and the input fields inside it (_method and authenticity_token) are hidden, so it usually has no effect on the HTML page, but sometimes you need to have a CSS class on it to avoid some layout/float issues.

This patch adds a configuration option that can be used like this:


config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form.merge!(:class=>'hideMe')
config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form.merge!(:class=>'hideMe', :style=>'display:none')

version.body-html:
The DIV tag generated inside form_for and form_tag by default has the style 'margin:0;padding:0' and the input fields inside it (_method and authenticity_token) are hidden, so it usually has no effect on the HTML page, but sometimes you need to have a CSS class on it to avoid some layout/float issues.

This patch adds a configuration option that can be used like this:


config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form = {:class=>'hideMe'}
config.action_view.html_options_for_extra_tag_in_form = {:class=>'hideMe', :style=>'display:none'}

version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body-html:
I think just having a display: inline on the div, or using a span tag, would solve most of the layout issues.

Also, I recently came across an issue with this when the form had display: inline and the div caused a linebreak. However, this is sometimes fixable. I was able to style that by adding a class on the form because I didn't have other divs in there:

form.blah div { display: inline }
version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body:
I just ran into this myself. In looking into it I began to wonder why the hidden field is wrapped in a tag at all? My understanding is that hidden fields are inline and don't take up any room in the layout by default so why wrap it?
At the very least the div tag should have a class added to it and/or have display:none set to remove it from the layout completely.
But unless there is a reason to wrap it in the first place, why not simply remove the div wrapper entirely?
version.body-html:
I just ran into this myself. In looking into it I began to wonder why the hidden field is wrapped in a tag at all? My understanding is that hidden fields are inline and don't take up any room in the layout by default so why wrap it?

At the very least the div tag should have a class added to it and/or have display:none set to remove it from the layout completely.

But unless there is a reason to wrap it in the first place, why not simply remove the div wrapper entirely?

version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body: I don't know the specifics by heart, but my FireFox HTML validator plugin complains if I have an INPUT tag inside a form that isn't wrapped by a DIV or P tag.
version.body-html: I don't know the specifics by heart, but my FireFox HTML validator plugin complains if I have an INPUT tag inside a form that isn't wrapped by a DIV or P tag.

version.body: what about simply adding :class => "authenticityTokenWrapper" so you can style it as you like with plain old CSS?

version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body:
Although, you can already use CSS to select by the name attribute of the element:
@@@ css form#new_model div input[name="authenticity_token"] { display: none; background-color: #fff;} @@@
version.body-html:
Although, you can already use CSS to select by the name attribute of the element:

 form#new_model div input[name="authenticity_token"] { display: none; background-color: #fff;}
version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body: We need to be able to target the DIV though, not the hidden input within it.
version.body-html: We need to be able to target the DIV though, not the hidden input within it.
version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body:
Ok, yeah, I definitely see that. It would be an improvement to have an id on it. I guess you could do this:
@@@ css form#new_model div[style="margin: 0pt; padding: 0pt; display: inline;"] @@@ but that seems kinda creaky and not future-proof. It should be by design. The above is just another work-around.
version.body-html:
Ok, yeah, I definitely see that. It would be an improvement to have an id on it. I guess you could do this:

form#new_model div[style="margin: 0pt; padding: 0pt; display: inline;"]

but that seems kinda creaky and not future-proof. It should be by design. The above is just another work-around.
version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body: we've run into the same issue. worked around by copying the output of the form helper into the view, replacing the urls with url_for, and deleting the wrap around div (we have our own div). I would prefer the simple solution of including a className in order to style if needed.
version.body-html: we've run into the same issue. worked around by copying the output of the form helper into the view, replacing the urls with url_for, and deleting the wrap around div (we have our own div). I would prefer the simple solution of including a className in order to style if needed.
version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body: Yup, including a className would be the best solution for most of the cases.
version.body-html: Yup, including a className would be the best solution for most of the cases.
version.title: Patch to add html options to the div that wraps the authenticity_token input field

version.body:
"The div is for HTML4.01/XHTML1.0 strict compliance." There's more info about this in the old Rails Trac: http://dev.rubyonrails.org/ticket/10422.
Adding inline margin/padding is bad practice as it doesn't separate markup from style. Although not a perfect solution, my vote would be to add :class => "authenticityTokenWrapper" and perhaps display:none as the default.
version.body-html:
"The div is for HTML4.01/XHTML1.0 strict compliance." There's more info about this in the old Rails Trac: http://dev.rubyonrails.org/ticket/10422.

Adding inline margin/padding is bad practice as it doesn't separate markup from style.
Although not a perfect solution, my vote would be to add :class => "authenticityTokenWrapper" and perhaps display:none as the default.

The resources of the Rails core team are limited, and so we are asking for your help. If you can still reproduce this error on the 3-0-stable branch or on master, please reply with all of the information you have about it and add "[state:open]" to your comment. This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.
